title: Newspaper headlines: Couriers 'charged £150 for day off ill'
text: Messenger Image caption Couriers working for parcel delivery company DPD face being charged £150 a day if they cannot find cover when they are ill, the Guardian reports. The paper quotes a driver as saying that he received the fine after suffering an upset stomach. Image caption The Daily Mirror says Sir Bruce Forsyth credits the NHS for saving his life after he spent five nights in intensive care following a severe chest infection. The paper quotes a friend as saying he would be "behind" a march against public sector cuts. Image caption The Times focuses its front page on Brexit, reporting that the UK can leave the European Union without having to pay a multi-billion pound "divorce settlement". The paper says the news represents a "significant boost" to Prime Minister Theresa May's negotiating hand. Image caption The Daily Express also leads on the same story, saying the UK can leave the EU "without having to pay a penny". Image caption The Telegraph reports that companies which use "confusing and misleading" smallprint will face a "government crackdown" designed to protect consumers. Image caption The Daily Mail leads on the story of a mother who has been "given a month" to save her baby's life. Connie Yates has been granted the time by the High Court to secure a "pioneering treatment" for her son, Charlie, the paper says. Image caption The Sun reports that burglars ransacked Chelsea footballer John Terry's house while he was on a skiing holiday. Friends of the ex-England captain are said to fear that the raiders may have got the idea after seeing photos posted on Terry's Instagram account. Image caption And finally, the Daily Star says Sir Rod Stewart has apologised for staging a "mock execution". Bethany Haines - daughter of David Haines, who was beheaded by so-called Islamic State - is said to have called Sir Rod "an absolute disgrace".
